case_vignette: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh! She initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past weeks! Her temperature is 36!7°C (98°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg! Physical examination shows a 0!8-cm hyperpigmented papule! When the skin lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inwards! A photograph of the lesion is shown!
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painless, non-itchy skin lesion on my right thigh that has slowly grown over the past month.
Can you describe the appearance of the lesion? Is it elevated, colored, or does it have a distinct border?
The lesion is a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented (darker colored) papule, which means it's slightly raised from the skin.
Have you experienced any similar lesions elsewhere on your body, either now or in the past?
No, I have not experienced any similar lesions elsewhere on my body.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin cancer?
I don't have any personal or family history of skin cancer.
Have you had any recent skin injuries or trauma to the area where the lesion developed?
No, I haven't had any recent skin injuries or trauma to the area where the lesion developed.
Have you noticed any changes in sensation, bleeding, or ulceration in the area of the lesion?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in sensation, bleeding, or ulceration in the area of the lesion.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatofibroma
